fields.description:
As per conversation with Nick and Michael, we want to clean up the JS so that our pages behave in a predictable and non-flakey manner. This will allow us to improve our automated tests and make them in turn less flakey. This in turn will allow us to have meaningful build information. When a test fails, it should be a definitive failure and not one due to flakey JS/flakey tests.

Conditions for Development:
We won't start this until our tested browsers are upgraded to Chrome + FF latest

fields.description:
This one isn't very obvious, but something I came across.

If I have two issues:
* ABC-123 - a normal issue, which is ranked higher than
* ABC-456 - a parent issue with some sub-tasks

If I convert ABC-123 to be a sub-task of ABC-456, what should the ranking of ABC-123 be in relation to ABC-456's existing sub-tasks? At the moment, it becomes the lowest ranked child of ABC-456. But since it was ranked _above_ the parent previously, should it not become the _highest_ ranked sub-task?
fields.summary: Should higher ranking of an issue be preserved if converting it to a sub-task of a lower issue?

fields.description:

* One which I don't (e.g. *Project B*)

And I display both those projects on a Rapid View, I can 
* rank an issue from *Project A* above an issue from *Project B*, but I _cannot_;
* rank the same issue from *Project B* below the same issue from *Project A*.

It seems odd that although I can achieve the same outcome, I can successfully do it one way but not the other.
fields.summary: Rank permissions in a multi-project environment don't seem to make sense

Outcome:

* Yet the issues which you were allowed to rank have successfully been ranked

It's a bit confusing - my initial thought was that the entire operation should have been aborted.

fields.description:
Hi we found that that the GH statistics burndown chart works ok for Daily, well except that its completely unreadable because you can't zoom the graph,but aside from that it basically works.  However if you group by Children, then it doesn't work.  Basically its only counting the story points for issues which were explicitly marked with a Fix Version of one of the children and not also including:

- those marked with the parent version
- those closed in the same date range as a child version and marked with the parent version.

Here is an example scenario:

So, lets say I make a parent version 1.0.0 and I then make a child version 1.0.1, and the start date for 1.0.1 is Jan 1st, and its ;end date is Jan 3rd.

Now lets say I create a story with 4 points, and I closed it on Jan 2nd, and I set the Fix Version (when I close) to be 1.0.1 (the child version).

If I now go to the statistics burndown chart and group by children, it shows zero points left. Perfect! All good.

But...if I instead do this:

    open the story with 4 points
    on Jan 2nd close it, and set Fix Version to 1.0.0 (the parent version)
    go to tteh statistics burndown chart and group by children.

It will show 4 points remaining.

We believe what is happening is that even though the documentation says that the grouping is by custom time segments (i.e. jan 1st to the jan 3rd), this is not actually how the chart works.

Instead the chart is only collecting into a child bar, the stories that were explicitly set to that version.

We tested in our instance of JIRA and we found that this is how the chart is working.

Why this is wrong:

1) the daily chart isn't working like that, so its inconsistent.

2) if you manage a large team, getting all 200 designers to properly select
the explicit Fix Version for the child sprint is (in theory) correct, but
not practical. Policing all 200 designers every day is just not practical.

When grouping by children, it should include in child versions issues that were either closed during the same time period for the sprint (presuming they have at least the right parent version).

If you have sub-teams working on different parent versions at the same time, then you can't just pick the stories that were closed within the same time range as a sub-version, they might be completely unrelated! But if the users at least set the fix version to parent version (giving you enough context), then the the child-versions should be inferred from their date ranges and when the story was closed.

This would ensure that that statistics burndown chart would show the same value sin both daily and children views.

For this particular issue; we have exactly this case, all of the designers closed the stories during sprints, but for whatever reason, many of them closed the stories with the parent version instead of the exact sprint version. So the daily chart works fine, but the children chart is busted, because it isn't being smart enough to match up the dates when the stories were closed with the child versions.

It should be able to do that because the Fix version was set to the parent version, so the tool should have enough context to know which sub-versions to map to.
fields.summary: Greenhopper Statistics Burndown (Grouped By Children) Should be Date Aware

* Go to the board configuration tab

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-3811].
  {panel}

If I go to a project's *Agile* tab, then on the right click on the *Hours*, *Issues*, or *Flow* tab, I do not see more than 1 day's worth of data if the selected version's *Start date* is blank. This makes these charts useless.

Attached is an example from a project that has been ongoing for about 2 weeks and which will end in about 3.5 weeks. All I see is what happened today. This gives me no clue of where we're coming from or whether I have appropriate progress.

The same happens if I create a Greenhopper Agile Gadget on my dashboard.

It would be better if the chart would start from the start date of the earliest recorded work or meaningful action on an issue (e.g., not the issue's creation date) if the version lacks a start date.
fields.summary: Charts start on first day of recorded work if no start date specified for version

fields.description:
There are currently a number of customer comments on the page asking for examples of how or when one might effectively use contexts. I tend to agree - being a new user, it is not immediately clear how this functionality can help the customer. The first place they would turn to would be documentation, but aside from the technicalities of what is displayed in each screen, there is no high-level overview of what Contexts are useful for.

One question that might prompt better clarification could be: 
What if I wanted a quick way to see a subset of my issues on the Planning Board?

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Using+Contexts+to+Filter+and+Highlight+Issues
fields.summary: Add usage example to the Contexts page to clarify what Contexts are good for

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
If a Studio instance is running with an On Demand license that does not include GreenHopper, we expect Green Hopper to be unavailable.

Currently, this works when the Studio instance is provisioned with a license that does not include GreenHopper. However, if the instance has previously had an On Demand license with GreenHopper active, the plugin remains available after applying a new license with no GreenHopper. On the other hand, transitions to an 'expired' GreenHopper license work as expected.

So:
* {{Active -> expired}}: GreenHopper is unavailble. *OK*
* {{Active -> no license}}:  GreenHopper is availble. *Problem*
* {{Active -> expired -> no license}}:  GreenHopper is availble. *Problem*
fields.summary: On Demand Licensing: GreenHopper does not honour transitions to an On Demand license that does not include a GreenHopper license.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Currently the planning board allows filtering by version and component. It would be nice to be able to filter by (multiple) issue Types, e.g. to be able to now show bugs. 

This should be added in the url so a posted url could open the Planning board as desired.
fields.summary: Task board - add Filtering on label

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The version synchroniser is not working when resolving an issue.

Suppose I have the following version hierarchy :
Version 1
 +---- Version 1.2
 +---- Version 1.2
Version 2
 +---- Version 2.2
 +---- Version 2.2

In the GreenHopper Listeners configuration, I activated the Versions Synchoniser.

If I edit an issue and I change the FixVersion to "1.2", the Versions Synchroniser will properly update the fix version to "Version1, Version1.2"

However, if I set the FixVersion to "1.2" in the "resolving an issue" popup, then the fix version wont be updated following the version hierarchy.
fields.summary: Versions synchroniser not working when resolving issues

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
With On Demand Licensing, users manage their plugin licenses through MAC. Therefore, the licensing screen in JIRA admin should not be available to customers when GreenHopper is running in On Demand (regardless of whether GreenHopper has an active license). 

However, the GreenHopper admin menu currently includes a License section that is visible to customer admins (including a textarea for manually updating the GH license, which is not applicable in On Demand).

License information should only be visible to sysadmins (i.e. Atlassian Support). Any information about updating the license that might be seen by customers should link to MAC, and should not include an interface for updating the license directly in the product.
fields.summary: On Demand Licensing: GreenHopper License screen should not be displayed when running in an On Demand instance

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
(!) Testing Notes (!)

Q: What happens in the case with an issue that has a subtask not captured by the filter?
A: (/) Nothing - the count is for parent issues and not sub-tasks, so the count will not be affected.

Q: Test to see this works with Stories Swimlane config, as well as Queries.
A: (/) Still works, though it is less clear what the issue count refers to given that you do not see the parent issue in the column it is in.

Q: What about negative numbers?
A: (/) They continue to not be allowed - same input controls for constraints as before.

Q: Is this customizable for individual constraints, or globally for all constraints?
A: (/) For the whole board, not individual columns

Q: What if the last parent is removed from that column but it's subtasks remain?
A: (/) The count drops to zero.

Q: What happens if there is no subtask issuetype?
A: (/) Nothing - the count should not be affected by issues which do not exist

Q: What happens when there are quick filters active that filter out parent issues? What happens when there are quick filters active that filter out sub-task issues?
A: (/) The count should still display the appropriate number of issues - so if column constraint excludes sub tasks then filtering out parents should set all visible counts to 0.
fields.summary: As a rapid board owner I would like to be able to have a column constraint for "Issues, excluding Sub-Tasks"

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Rapid board throw error below while using Internet Explorer 7. 

{noformat}
An exception occurred

Please try refreshing the page, or contact your administrator / Atlassian Support if the problem continues.

Details
Exception: 'JSON' is null or not an object
Resource: http://10.60.1.130:8081/secure/RapidBoard.jspa
Line: 238
Environment
Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1)
{noformat}

*Steps to replicate*
# Setup new JIRA 4.4 and enable GreenHopper
# Access Rapid board.
# Error as shown in the screenshot thrown.
|

*Finding*
* I was able to replicate this problem with both customer and new clean instance. 
* Only Happened in IE 7 ( Tested with IE8, Chrome and Firefox ). 
* IE 7 is supported as mentioned in [GreenHopper Supported Platform |http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Supported+Platformshttp://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Supported+Platforms] but not recommended.

*Workaround* 
Use other browser or upgrade to IE 8.
fields.summary: Rapid Board doesn't work with Rapid Board

fields.description: When trying to create a Rapidview, if you have a filter with a very long name, the dropdown to assign the filter tries to render the entire name, which can go off the screen unreasonably. There should be a character limit to the dropdown, and this might be a problem with all dropdowns.
fields.summary: New Rapidview Dialog (maybe others) tries to render superlong dropdown for long filter names

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
As a GH administrator
I'd like to be able to specify issue count contraints per column and/or per swimlane

For example, I have 3 columns:

TODO, IN PROGRESS, DONE

and two swimlanes:

Expedite
Everything Else

I'd like an explicit max of 1 issue for TODO/Expedite, max of 5 for TODO/Everything Else

This could be taken further by having swimlane constraints override column constraints (so we can only have 1 expedite issue on the board at any time)
fields.summary: enable constraints per column+swimlane

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: I recently upgraded Jira from 4.2.4_b591 to 4.4.1. Greenhopper has been upgraded to 5.7.2. On the taskboard (and others) I used to be able to click the issue number and the issue was brought up in a popup. Now the page performs a full refresh to the issue I clicked. This wouldn't be much of an issue, but there is no way to get back. Clicking the back button returns a "confirm submission" browser message which forces a refresh. It's all very odd.
fields.summary: No Issue popups on taskboard, planning board, etc.

fields.description:
GreenHopper Days Remaining gadget don't detect child version end date properly if its parent version didn't set with a end date.

Step to reproduce:
* Create 2 versions - *A* and *B* in Agile and 1 child version - *C* for version *B*
* Set version A end date to be in next month
* Set version C end date to be in current month without giving version B any end date
* Add GreenHopper Days Remaining gadget in the dashboard and select *Next End Date Scheduled (auto)*
* Save it and the gadget will show remaining days for version *A* instead of *C*
fields.summary: GreenHopper Days Remaining gadget don't detect child version end date properly

fields.description:
Please implement a way that I can see the total number of points in the backlog, or how many points are in a particular status. I currently use the Issues Navigator to export and use filters in Excel which is extremely primitive for such an expensive tool. I would also like to know if there is a dashboard feature / plugin which I can get a view on a particular project (preferably where I can select the 'fix versions' by filter as well) and have the following summary of the current situation:

Points Issue Status

60 Done
16 In QA
47 In Progress
26 Blocked
85 Not started

234 Total points in backlog

Please implement this as soon as possible because it's extremely difficult to track projects without this view!
fields.summary: Implement a way to see the total number of points in the backlog!

fields.description:
If unregistering one component fails due to some environmental problems, we should catch all exceptions and still try to execute the other ones, to ensure that as many connections as possible are cut.

To be tested:
- regular plugin startup / shutdown
- disabling and reenabling
- JIRA start with bundled disabled
- JIRA start with bundled enabled
- JIRA start with bundled enabled but updated
fields.summary: Try/catch - proove all unregistering calls in Launcher

fields.description:
In the Greenhopper list view, the columns of sub-task are slightly offset compared to the columns of top-level issues (see screen shots).

Steps to reproduce:
* Open a Greenhopper planning board, e.g. [in Jira's own issue tracker|https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/VersionBoard.jspa?selectedBoardId=&pageType=PlanningBoard&subType=ComponentBoard&type=CB&selectedProjectId=10240&colPage=1]
* Enable the list view
* Find an item with sub-task, e.g. in Jira's own issue tracker there is currently one in the Unscheduled version on the first page
* For the sub-task and other issues, compare the alignment of columns to the right of the description. The task's columns have a slight offset to the left
fields.summary: Columns in sub-tasks misaligned in Greenhopper list view
